definition: to work to no avail (idiom)
disciple/apprentice/believer/on foot/bare or empty/to no avail/only/prison sentence
surname Tu
to toil/labor/laborer/to put sb to trouble (of doing sth)/meritorious deed/to console (Taiwan pr. [lao4] for this sense)
not to have/no/none/not/to lack/un-/-less
meritorious deed or service/achievement/result/service/accomplishment/work (physics)

sentences.english: The wind cannot be caught in a net.
All our efforts availed us little in trying to effect a change.
sentences.chinese: 在企圖實現一個變革中我們徒勞無功。

sentences.english: We wasted all day on a wild-goose chase.
sentences.chinese: 我們徒勞無功的浪費了一整天。

sentences.english: All the entreating of the coast guard was in vain.
sentences.chinese: 海岸警衛隊的隊員，無論怎樣勸說都徒勞無功。

sentences.english: This would be as futile as trying to tame a volcano.
sentences.chinese: 這樣做無疑像要馴服火山一樣徒勞無功。

sentences.english: So I started looking online, also in vain.
sentences.chinese: 所以我開始在網上查找，也是徒勞無功。

sentences.english: But the two-toed tree toad tried in vain.
sentences.chinese: 可是，二趾蟾蜍徒勞無功。

sentences.english: Wild-goose chases may happen sometimes during an investigation.
sentences.chinese: 在一項調查的過程中，有時也許產生徒勞無功的結果。

sentences.english: The wind cannot be caught in net.
Change for change's sake is stupid and enervating.
sentences.chinese: 爲改變而改變是愚蠢而徒勞無功的。

sentences.english: But the dramatic scenes of hired workers washing oil off beaches turned out to be images of futility.
sentences.chinese: 但工人們在沙灘上衝洗油污的結果卻是徒勞無功。

sentences.english: I made many attempts, all in vain.
sentences.chinese: 我嘗試了多次，都徒勞無功。

sentences.english: It is in vain, sir, extenuate the matter.
sentences.chinese: 先生，企圖使事態減輕是徒勞無功的。

sentences.english: It is aimless to cast water into the sea.
sentences.chinese: 投杯水於大海，徒勞無功。

sentences.english: The caged bird flapped its wings in a vain attempt to fly away.
sentences.chinese: 籠子哩的鳥拍打着翅膀想飛走，但卻徒勞無功。

definition: retort with challenging questions/debate
to judge
to be reluctant to give up a post
to play deaf-mute
lit. wading in mud and water/a slovenly job/sloppy
lit. you hoodwink me and I cheat you (idiom); fig. mutual deception/each tries to outwit the other/dog eats dog and devil take the hindmost
outward devotion but inner opposition (idiom); to pay lip service/to agree overtly, but oppose in secret
lit. the salted fish turns over (idiom)/fig. to experience a reversal of fortune
a fish that escaped the net (idiom)/(fig.) sb or sth that slips through the net
lit. severe floods and fierce beasts (idiom)/fig. great scourges/extremely dangerous or threatening things
unification and independence
to gain nothing/to end up empty-handed
bureaucracy
to become a mere formality
victor/winner
to speak forcefully and with justice (idiom); to argue with the courage of one's convictions
